entry.content:
Unsupervised learning

regression vs. classification

why unsupervised learning?

  • few of data are labeled
  • pre-train an unsupervised model
  • anomaly detection - learn what data distribution typically looks like
  • cheaper than supervised learning

Generative models

a generative model is a class of statistical model that contrasts with discriminative models.

informally

  • discriminative model - classifier dataâˆ¼pdata(x)\text{data}\sim p_{data}(x)dataâˆ¼pdataâ€‹(x)
  • generative model - generate new data instances generatedÂ samplesâˆ¼pmodel(x)\text{generated samples}\sim p_{model}(x)generatedÂ samplesâˆ¼pmodelâ€‹(x)

generative model includes the distribution of the data itself and tells you how likely a given example is.

for example, models that predict the next word in a sequence are typically generative models.

many kinds

Generative models are hard

  • have to model more - generative model try to model how data is placed throughout the space
  • a generative model for images might capture some difficult correlations.

Autoencoder

Traditional Autoencoder (AE)

an AE is a neural network that is trained to attempt to copy its input to its output

given data xxx (no labels) we would like to learn function fff (encoder) and ggg (decoder) s.t.:

h=f(x)x^=g(h)x^=g(f(x))=xh=f(x)\\\hat x=g(h)\\\hat x=g(f(x))=xh=f(x)x^=g(h)x^=g(f(x))=x

where g is an approximation of the identify function

h=f(x)=s(Wx+b)h=f(x)=s(Wx+b)h=f(x)=s(Wx+b) is the latent or hidden representation or code and sss is a non-linearity function.

x^=g(h)=s(WTh+bâ€²)\hat x=g(h)=s(W^Th+b')x^=g(h)=s(WTh+bâ€²) is xxxâ€™s reconstruction.

Motivation

  • learning the identity function ggg everywhere is not especially useful
  • autoencoders are restricted in ways that allow them to copy only approximately.
  • traditionally an autoencoder is used for dimensionality reduction and feature learning

Training an encoder

training set is no-label.

using SGD

loss function: L2 Norm

undercomplete vs overcomplete AE

AE is undercomplete if hidden representation has smaller dimensionality than the input

  • good feature for the training distribution
  • bad for other types of input

AE is overcomplete if hidden representation has larger dimensionality than the input

  • no guarantee that the hidden units will extract meaningful structure
  • higher* dimension code helps model a more complex distribution - good for training a linear classifier.

Stacked AE - deep

deep is better

  • more representational power
  • easier for similar datapoints to group together.
  • better separation of classes

Latent space

the space in which the encoding exists is called the latent space or the hidden space

if AE is undercomplete, the compressed latent representation hhh is often called the bottleneck

what if we tr to interpolate æ’å€¼ between two latent space? hi=Î±h1+(1âˆ’Î±)h2h_i=\alpha h_1+(1-\alpha)h_2hiâ€‹=Î±h1â€‹+(1âˆ’Î±)h2â€‹

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å‘ç°ï¼ŒÎ±\alphaÎ± ä» 0 åˆ° 1ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°çš„ hih_ihiâ€‹ åƒ h1h_1h1â€‹ ä»£è¡¨çš„ä¸œè¥¿å˜å¾—è¶Šæ¥è¶Šåƒ h2h_2h2â€‹ ä»£è¡¨çš„ä¸œè¥¿äº†

Problem with simple autoencoders

  • latent space may not be continuous
  • å®¹æ˜“å˜æˆ replicate

solution: variational autoencoders

Regularization

motivation: learn meaningful features without altering the codeâ€™s dimensions

solution: imposing other constraints on the network

Sparse AE

suppose the AE has learned this hidden representation features.

It has just remembered the data, not learned it. This will not generalize well to unseen data

the image is decomposed into a combination of sparse features:

  • if our learned features are sparse, we can generalize better
  • sparse means: most activations are 0 except a few that are close to 1.

Let hj(lBn)h_j^{(l_{Bn})}hj(lBnâ€‹)â€‹ denote the activation of jjj-th hidden unit of the autoencoder

Let hj(lBn)(x)h_j^{(l_{Bn})}(x)hj(lBnâ€‹)â€‹(x) be activation of this specific node on a give input xxx.

Let Ï^j=1nâˆ‘i=1n[hj(lBn)(xi)]\hat\rho_j=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n[h_j^{(l_{Bn})}(x^{i})]Ï^â€‹jâ€‹=n1â€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹[hj(lBnâ€‹)â€‹(xi)] be the average activation of hidden unit jjj.

we would like to enforce the constraint Ï^j=Ï\hat\rho_j=\rhoÏ^â€‹jâ€‹=Ï where Ï\rhoÏ is a sparsity parameter, typically small.

in other words, we want the average activation of each neuron jjj to be close to Ï\rhoÏ.

we penalize Ï^j\hat\rho_jÏ^â€‹jâ€‹ for deviating from Ï\rhoÏ

penalty term: âˆ‘j=1SBnKL(Ïâˆ£Ï^j)\sum_{j=1}^{S_{Bn}}KL(\rho|\hat\rho_j)âˆ‘j=1SBnâ€‹â€‹KL(Ïâˆ£Ï^â€‹jâ€‹)

KLKLKL is a Kullback-Liebler divergence function, SBnS_{Bn}SBnâ€‹ is the number of units in the hidden layer

KL(Ïâˆ£Ï^j)=0KL(\rho|\hat\rho_j)=0KL(Ïâˆ£Ï^â€‹jâ€‹)=0 if Ï^j=Ï\hat\rho_j=\rhoÏ^â€‹jâ€‹=Ï

overall loss function: JS(W)=J(W)+Î²âˆ‘j=1SBnKL(Ïâˆ£Ï^j)J_S(W)=J(W)+\beta\sum_{j=1}^{S_{Bn}}KL(\rho|\hat\rho_j)JSâ€‹(W)=J(W)+Î²âˆ‘j=1SBnâ€‹â€‹KL(Ïâˆ£Ï^â€‹jâ€‹)

J(W)=12âˆ‘i=1nâˆ£âˆ£x^(i)âˆ’x(i)âˆ£âˆ£J(W)=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^n||\hat x^{(i)}-x^{(i)}||J(W)=21â€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹âˆ£âˆ£x^(i)âˆ’x(i)âˆ£âˆ£

we need to know Ï^j\hat\rho_jÏ^â€‹jâ€‹ before hand, so we have to compute a forward pass on the whole training set.

Recap

cross-entropy: H(p,q)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1npilogâ¡2(qi)H(p,q)=-\sum_{i=1}^np_i\log_2(q_i)H(p,q)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹piâ€‹log2â€‹(qiâ€‹)

KL divergence: DKL(pâˆ£âˆ£q)=H(p,q)âˆ’H(p)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1npilogâ¡2qiâˆ’(âˆ’âˆ‘i=1npilogâ¡2pi)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1npilogâ¡2qipiD_{KL}(p||q)=H(p,q)-H(p)=-\sum_{i=1}^np_i\log_2{q_i}-(-\sum_{i=1}^np_i\log_2p_i)=-\sum_{i=1}^np_i\log_2\frac{q_i}{p_i}DKLâ€‹(pâˆ£âˆ£q)=H(p,q)âˆ’H(p)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹piâ€‹log2â€‹qiâ€‹âˆ’(âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹piâ€‹log2â€‹piâ€‹)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹piâ€‹log2â€‹piâ€‹qiâ€‹â€‹

Denoising AE

aim to encode the input to learn and describe latent attributes of the data

try to undo the effect of a corruption process stochastically applied to the input

model isnâ€™t able to simply develop a mapping which memorizes the training data, becuase input and target output are not the same

æ›´ç¨³å®š robust çš„æ¨¡å‹ï¼šåœ¨è¾“å…¥çš„æ—¶å€™åŠ ä¸Šå™ªå£°ï¼Œç›®æ ‡è¾“å‡ºè¿˜æ˜¯åŸå›¾

x^=g(f(x~))=x\hat x=g(f(\widetilde x))=xx^=g(f(x))=x where x~\widetilde xx is a copy of xxx that has been corrupted by some noise process

example of noise

random assignment of subset of inputs to 0 with probability vvv.

Gaussian additive noise.

training

reconstruction x^\hat xx^ computed from the corrupted input x~\widetilde xx

loss function compares x^\hat xx^ reconstruction with the noiseless xxx

what does it learn?

the correlations of xxxâ€™s features

based on those relations we can learn a more â€œnot prone to changesâ€ model

we are forcing the hidden layer to learn a generalized structure of the data

The DAE is trained to map a corrupted data point back to the manifold. DAE ç»è¿‡è®­ç»ƒï¼Œå¯ä»¥å°†æŸåçš„æ•°æ®ç‚¹æ˜ å°„å›æµå½¢ã€‚

Going convolutional

we can replace the fully connected layers with convolutional layers

Variational autoencoders

very similar to the regular autoencoder

unique property: latent space are continuous (by design), allowing random sampling and interpolation

how?

by making its encoder not output an encoding vector of size nnn, but rather outputting two vectors of size nnn.

a vector of means Î¼\muÎ¼, and another vector of standard deviations Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ

probabilistic nature using a sampling layer

Random sampling layer

the stochastic generation means, that even for the same input, while the mean and standard deviations remain the same, the actual encoding will somewhat vary on every single pass simply due to sampling.

å°†è¾“å‡ºæ•´æˆäº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒè€Œä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç¡®å®šçš„å€¼ã€‚

  • the hidden layer outputs the parameters of a vector of random variables of length nnn
  • the iii-th element of Î¼\muÎ¼ and Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ represents the mean and standard deviation of the iii-th random variable xix_ixiâ€‹, from which we sample to obtain the sampled encoding, which we pass onward to the decoder

Probabilistic nature of VAE

not only is a single point in latent space referring to a sample of that class, but all nearby points refer to the same as well

the decoder is exposed to a range of variations

results in a smooth latent space

Local smoothness is not enough

  • if the encoder learns to cluster samples apart, the decoder will be able to reconstruct the training data better

  • we want encodings all of which are as close as possible to each other while still being distinct, allowing smooth interpolation, and enabling the construction of new samples.

    æœ€å¥½è¿™äº› smooth çš„ç±»åˆ«åˆ†å¸ƒèƒ½ç´§å¯†æŒ¨ç€ï¼Œåˆ†å¼€äº†å°±ä¸å¥½

solution:

  • KL divergence in the loss function
  • for VAEs, the KL loss is equivalent to the sum of all the KL divergences between the latent component Ziâˆ¼N(Î¼i,Ïƒi2)Z_i\sim N(\mu_i,\sigma_i^2)Ziâ€‹âˆ¼N(Î¼iâ€‹,Ïƒi2â€‹) in ZZZ. and the standard normal, where Î¼i=0,Ïƒi2=1\mu_i=0,\sigma_i^2=1Î¼iâ€‹=0,Ïƒi2â€‹=1
  • KL loss term: âˆ‘i=1nÏƒi2+Î¼i2âˆ’logâ¡Ïƒiâˆ’1\sum_{i=1}^n\sigma_i^2+\mu_i^2-\log\sigma_i-1âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹Ïƒi2â€‹+Î¼i2â€‹âˆ’logÏƒiâ€‹âˆ’1
  • we still minimize similarity as well 12âˆ‘âˆ£âˆ£x^âˆ’xâˆ£âˆ£2\frac{1}{2}\sum||\hat x-x||^221â€‹âˆ‘âˆ£âˆ£x^âˆ’xâˆ£âˆ£2

Effect of KL loss term

encourages the encoder to distribute all encoding, evenly around the center of the latent space

Optimizing similarity and KL loss, results in the generation of a latent space which maintains the similarity of nearby encodings on the local scale via clustering, yet globally, is very densely packed near the latent space origin.

Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)

Density estimation

goal of probabilistic generative models: fund model s.t. pdata(x)=pmodel(x)p_{data}(x)=p_{model}(x)pdataâ€‹(x)=pmodelâ€‹(x)

explicitly model density function (distribution)

  • é«˜æ–¯åˆ†å¸ƒã€VAE çš„ latent è®¡ç®—

implicit: GAN - just learn to generate samples from distribution

motivation of GAN

problem: want to sample from complex, high-dimensional training distribution. no direct way to do this

solution: sample from a simple distribution.

System of 2 neural network competing against each other in a 0-sum game framework

discriminator network: try to distinguish between real and fake images

generator network: try to fool the discriminator by generating real-looking images

Training GAN

D(x)D(x)D(x) represents the probability that input xxx came from the real data rather than the generator

G(z)G(z)G(z) takes random input noise vector zzz and transforms it into an image

minibatch consists of

  • {x(i)}i=1m\{x^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^m{x(i)}i=1mâ€‹ examples from the real distribution
  • {z(i)}i=1m\{z^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^m{z(i)}i=1mâ€‹ samples from a prior distribution (like Gaussian)

then, from the discriminatorâ€™s perspective, we would like to have

D(x(i))=1D(x^{(i)})=1D(x(i))=1 (real), D(G(z(i)))=0D(G(z^{(i)}))=0D(G(z(i)))=0 (fake) â‡’maxâ¡WDâˆ‘i=1mlogâ¡(D(x(i)))+logâ¡(1âˆ’D(G(z(i))))\Rightarrow\max_{W_D}\sum_{i=1}^m\log(D(x^{(i)}))+\log(1-D(G(z^{(i)})))â‡’maxWDâ€‹â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹log(D(x(i)))+log(1âˆ’D(G(z(i))))

but for generatorâ€™s perspective, we would like to have

D(G(z(i)))=1D(G(z^{(i)}))=1D(G(z(i)))=1 (fool the discriminator) â‡’minâ¡WGâˆ‘i=1mlogâ¡(1âˆ’D(G(z(i))))\Rightarrow\min_{W_G}\sum_{i=1}^m\log(1-D(G(z^{(i)})))â‡’minWGâ€‹â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹log(1âˆ’D(G(z(i))))

Loss function

minimax game

minâ¡WGmaxâ¡WDExâˆ¼pdatalogâ¡(D(x))+Ezâˆ¼pzlogâ¡(1âˆ’D(G(z)))=âˆ«pdata(x)logâ¡(D(x))dx+âˆ«pzlogâ¡(1âˆ’D(G(z)))dz\min_{W_G}\max_{W_D}\mathbb E_{x\sim p_{data}}\log(D(x))+\mathbb E_{z\sim p_z}\log(1-D(G(z)))\\=\int p_{data}(x)\log(D(x))\text dx+\int p_z\log(1-D(G(z)))\text dzWGâ€‹minâ€‹WDâ€‹maxâ€‹Exâˆ¼pdataâ€‹â€‹log(D(x))+Ezâˆ¼pzâ€‹â€‹log(1âˆ’D(G(z)))=âˆ«pdataâ€‹(x)log(D(x))dx+âˆ«pzâ€‹log(1âˆ’D(G(z)))dz

for a fixed generator, it can be shown that this minimax game has a global optimum for pdata(x)=pgenerator(x)p_{data}(x)=p_{generator}(x)pdataâ€‹(x)=pgeneratorâ€‹(x)

in that case, the discriminator canâ€™t distinguish the real from the fake, because

Dâˆ—(x)=Prâ¡(realâˆ£x)=pdata(x)pdata(x)+pgenerator(x)=12D^*(x)=\Pr(real|x)=\frac{p_{data}(x)}{p_{data}(x)+p_{generator}(x)}=\frac{1}{2}Dâˆ—(x)=Pr(realâˆ£x)=pdataâ€‹(x)+pgeneratorâ€‹(x)pdataâ€‹(x)â€‹=21â€‹

it works!

  • GGG has a reinforcement learning task
    • it knows when it does good but it is not given a supervised signal
    • RL is hard
    • back propagation through DDD provides GGG with a supervised signal; the better DDD is, the better this signal will be.
  • Canâ€™t describe optimum via a single loss
  • DDD is seldom fooled

Common problems in training GAN

hard to train!

  • non-convergence: the model parameters oscillate, destabilize and never converge

  • mode collapse: the generator collapses which produces limited varieties of samples

    è¡¨ç°ï¼šç”Ÿæˆå™¨å¾€å¾€åªç”Ÿæˆå•ä¸€ç±»å‹çš„æ•°æ®

  • diminished gradient: the discriminator gets to successful, so the generator gradient vanishes

  • unbalanced between generator and discriminator causing overfitting

  • highly sensitive to the hyperparameter selections

Some variation of GAN

Deep Convolutional GAN

aka DCGAN

åŠ äº†å·ç§¯æ“ä½œçš„å¯¹æŠ—ç”Ÿæˆç½‘ç»œ

Conditional GAN

aka CGAN

the original GAN generates data from random noise, but has no knowledge about class labels

CGAN aims to solve this by telling the generator to generate images of only one particular class, like a cat or dog

specifically, CGAN concatenates a one-hot vector yyy to the random noise vector zzz to result in an architecture.

Pix2Pix

CycleGAN - cycle consistency loss

ProGAN - progressive growing of GAN

WGAN - wasserstein GAN

SAGAN - self attention GAN

BigGAN

Summary

Auto encoders

  • best for dimensionality reduction / feature learning.
  • Not good at generating new samples due to discontinuities in latent space

variational autoencoders VAE

  • useful latent representation. better at generating new samples, but current sample quality not the best.

generative adversarial networks GAN

  • game-theoretic approach, best samples
  • but can be tricky and unstable to train

Duality

Mechanism design without money

House allocation

  • nnn participants, each with her own house
  • each participant has a ranking of all houses.
  • how can we redistribute the houses s.t. the participants are as happy as possible?
  • Top trading cycle (TTC) algorithm

Top trading cycle algorithm

NNN: set of participants

  • construct the directed graph GGG with the participants as nodes and edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) if the most preferred house for participant iii is that belonging to jjj.
  • compute all directed cycles in GGG
  • for every edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) of ever cycle CCC, give the house of jjj to iii
  • remove the nodes of CCC from set NNN.

Some facts

  • algorithm TTC is DSIC
  • first, every participant who gets a house at round kkk
    • prefers it compared to any other house, besides the ones given in earlier rounds
    • got it from someone who also got a house in round kkk
  • proof idea: no false reporting can give to participant iii a house that was given in a previous round
  • why? in any previous round, there is no edge from someone who got a house to participant iii.
  • interesting: the algorithm that sometimes doesnâ€™t redistribute any house is DSIC.

block coalition: a set of participants s.t. there is a way to redistribute their houses so that all prefer the new allocation

core allocation: an allocation that has no blocking coalition

The allocation computed by TTC is the unique core allocation
